Due Diligence Guidelines

Project Due Diligence Guidelines

Introduction

Committers play a very important role in the operation of open source projects. This document outlines the responsibilities and explains some of the basic concepts Committers need to understand in their role as a committer. If you are a  Committer, should you have any questions after reading this document, your questions should be submitted to the project's core team.

Contributors and Committers

Anyone who makes contributions to the project are considered to be Contributors. These Contributors submit contributions such as code, documentation, and other materials, through a number of channels including the wikis, mailing lists, and bug reporting system. In general, anyone may have access to these systems. However, passwords may be used for spam control purposes. Contributions made through the wikis and mailing lists are generally made when users chat and exchange ideas. Contribution of code is very rarely made through these channels. Code contributions would more likely be found attached to a bug report.

Contributors that have made significant contributions to the project may be promoted to Committer status. A Contributor may become a Committer once having been approved by the project's core team.   Committers have a responsibility to help ensure that all "upstream" content published is appropriate.  In the case of wikis and mailing list posts and bug reports, it is possible for Contributors to submit inappropriate content without the knowledge of Committers. If a Committer finds content on one of these systems that does not seem appropriate, based on the standards set out in this document or based on the Committer's good judgement and experience, they should contact the project's core team.

Committers receive write-access to the project that contributors do not have. Depending on the nature of their participation, this may include write-access to the CVS repository, the download servers, and the web site. Committed content in the CVS repository becomes immediately available to project visitors and users. More importantly, this content is used to create daily builds that may be downloaded by thousands of people each day and may be incorporated into many free and commercially-available software products. Due to the potential for downstream redistribution, Committers are required to help ensure that inappropriate content is not placed in the CVS repository. Content contributed to the webpages on the Project web site is less likely to be incorporated into software products. However, by their nature, they may be seen by visitors to the web site and their impact is generally more immediate.

Committers are usually contributors as well. In addition to incorporating and releasing content contributed by others, Committers may commit, often significant, contributions which they have developed themselves. Some Comitters may never commit any other content other than what they have authored themselves. Even though they may be more confident in the pedigree of their own contributions, they still need to ensure that their content is appropriate.

How Content is Received

All project "upstream" content submitted through any of the channels such as, wikis, mailing lists, and the bug reporting system or any of the other services, are licensed to others under the terms and conditions of the Common Public License. 

How Content is Distributed

Users and recipients of project content are granted rights to the content by the Common Public License.

Due Diligence Procedures

A Committer cannot always assume that contributed content can be freely used or redistributed. A Committer is obligated to ensure the appropriate due diligence has been completed before incorporating and redistributing content received from others. The following three steps should be used in determining if the contributed content is suitable for committing to Project:

  • Establish suitabiliy for the project.
  • If applicable, determine compatibility of the contribution's license with the BSD License.
  • Establish appropriateness of the content of the contribution based on the due diligence review.

These three steps should be used for all "significant" contributions. A "significant" contribution is a substantial amount of code or content that introduces major new functionality into the code base, or any code or module which will be distributed under any license other than the BSD License . Once the license compatibility has been confirmed, the Committer, with assistance from one or more Contributors, should complete the Project Contribution Questionnaire for the due diligence prior to committing the contribution to the Project project. For simple bug fixes and minor enhancements contributed under the BSD License,  the Committer is expected to ensure the appropriateness of the contribution.

The following information describes the guidelines to be considered by the Committers to ensure the appropriate due diligence has been completed on all contributions.

Appropriateness of Contributions

Before acepting and integrating contributions, the Committer needs to determine if the contribution is appropriate and necessary for the project.  Once the Committer is satisfied with the contribution, (e.g. license compatibility, confidentiality, copyright rights, patents, etc.) , as well as, its appropriateness and its availability for redistribution and modification by the project (e.g. does not contravene export control laws, does not contain profanity, meets acceptable standards of code quality and coding style etc.), then the contribution may be used.

If the contribution has any “legal” terms or conditions associated with it whatsoever (other than a simple statement saying the contribution is licensed under the BSD License) the contribution must be approved by the project's core team before being utilized. Possible such “legal” terms or conditions include anything referring to “copyright”, “patent”, “trade secret”, “confidential”, “license” or “rights,” or any other language purporting to grant or reserve any rights to use or distribute the contribution, or limit public distribution of the contribution.

Given the amount of time required to complete the due diligence process on these packages, the Committer should allow sufficient time for the appropriate due dilgence to be completed before committing the code to the repository.

Style & Quality

The GNU Programmer's Style Guide should be use when appropriate for all contributions.

Third-Party Content

There are cases where content redistributed at Project is not received as a contribution under the BSD License. Rather, the content was obtained from another source and is redistributed under another license. The most common case is a Committer who wishes to redistribute content maintained by another open source project, outside of project.  This must be approved by the project's core team.

Tracking Contributions

Tracking of each contribution within a project is very important from a legal point of view. As well, it allows for the appropriate aknowledgement of each contributor. Currently, this information about each contribution is typically maintained within the standard copyright and license notice contained within the source files. However, it is advisable that the project maintain a GNU style Change Log file to track the summary information about each contribution and links to related bug reports within a project. A well maintained Change Log file will be a valuable piece of information during the due diligence and preparation of a major release of a project.

Summary

To avoid downstream problems, it is a necessity to exercise the appropriate due diligence. In addition to these specific standards, the organization relies on Committers to exercise their own judgment with respect to other factors that may deem the contribution to be inappropriate for use. If a Committer has doubts about the appropriateness of the contribution for any reason, then that Committer should investigate and consult with the project's core team.
